#Text=Antonio Bonvisi
#Text=Antonio Bonvisi ( died 1558 ) was an Anglo-Italian merchant in London .
#Text=He was also a banker , and employed by the English government , as well as being an agent for the Italians appointed as Bishop of Worcester . [ 1 ]
#Text=He was on good terms with the English humanists of the time , and a close friend of Thomas More .
#Text=Life
#Text=His family was settled in England before his time , and he perhaps was born there , as his denisation does not appear to be on the patent rolls .
#Text=In 1513 he was already a thriving merchant , and laying the foundation of the great wealth for which he was famous .
#Text=In that year he received from the king , Henry VIII , a remission of customs for five years in repayment of a loan to the crown .
#Text=He dealt largely in wool , and also imported jewels and other foreign articles , for which Cardinal Wolsey was one of his principal customers . [ 2 ]

#Text=He acted as banker for the government , transmitting money and letters to ambassadors in France , Italy , and elsewhere , and sometimes through his correspondents obtaining earlier news of foreign events than the government did .
#Text=He was a patron and friend of learned men , more especially of those who had visited and studied in Italy .
#Text=Thomas Starkey , Thomas Wynter , Florence Volusenus , and others express their obligations to him .

#Text=Sir Thomas More , in one of his last letters from the Tower of London , speaks of himself as having been for nearly forty years ' not a guest , but a continual nursling of the house of Bonvisi , ' and styles Antonio the most faithful of his friends .
#Text=Reginald Pole also spoke highly of him ; when Mary came to the throne , Bonvisi acted as intermediary with Pole . [ 3 ]
#Text=He helped William Peto , who had fled to the Low Countries after preaching a sermon against King Henry VIII . [ 2 ]
#Text=He resided at London , in Crosby Hall , Bishopsgate Street ( Crosbyes Place it was then called ) . [ 4 ]
#Text=He at first leased it from the priory of St. Helen 's , a lease he bought from More .
#Text=After the dissolution of the priory , he purchased it from the king , together with a house in St. Mary Axe and the site of a friary in Moulsham , near Chelmsford .
#Text=This was in the period 1538 to 1542 .
#Text=The house in St. Mary Axe he sold to Balthazar Guercy , a distinguished fellow of the College of Physicians , and formerly medical attendant to Queen Catherine of Aragon .

#Text=At the beginning of the reign of Edward VI he settled his affairs , and later left for the continent ; the lease of Crosby House he made over to his tenants William Roper and William Rastell , and he also conveyed the ownership ; but almost all involved were Catholics who went into exile before he did . [ 5 ]
#Text=The house , with those of Dr John Clement and Guercy , was seized by the sheriffs of London , on 7 February 1550 , and came into the hands of Thomas Darcy , 1st Baron Darcy of Temple Hurst .
#Text=Bonvisi soon recovered it , during the reign of Queen Mary . [ 2 ] [ 5 ]
#Text=In the general pardon which concluded the acts of the parliament of 7 Edward VI ( 1553 )
#Text=he was specially excepted , together with Cardinal Pole , the two doctors above mentioned , John Story , and a few others .
#Text=He died on 7 December 1558 , and was buried at Leuven , leaving a nephew Benedict Bonvisi , son of his brother Martin , to inherit his English property . [ 2 ]
